# Blockbuster (entertainment)

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

For the video rental chain, see [Blockbuster LLC](/wiki/Blockbuster_LLC
"Blockbuster LLC").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Quo_Vadis_poster.jpg/220px-
Quo_Vadis_poster.jpg)](/wiki/File:Quo_Vadis_poster.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Quo_Vadis_poster.jpg "Enlarge")

Italian film _[Quo Vadis](/wiki/Quo_Vadis_\(1913_film\) "Quo Vadis \(1913
film\)")_ (1913) was the first blockbuster in the history of cinema

A **blockbuster** is a work of entertainment – especially a feature film, but
also applied to other media – which is highly popular and financially
successful. The term has also come to refer to any large-budget production
_intended_ for "blockbuster" status, aimed at mass markets with associated
merchandising, sometimes on a scale that meant the financial fortunes of a
film studio or a distributor could depend on it.

  * 1 History

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Blockbuster_\(entertainment\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

The term began to appear in the American press in the early 1940s,[1]
referring to [aerial bombs capable of destroying a whole block of
buildings](/wiki/Blockbuster_bomb "Blockbuster bomb").[2] It came to be
applied to movies as a metaphor, indicating something successful on a dramatic
scale. Successful films such as [_Quo Vadis_](/wiki/Quo_Vadis_\(1951_film\)
"Quo Vadis \(1951 film\)"), [_The Ten
Commandments_](/wiki/The_Ten_Commandments_\(1956_film\) "The Ten Commandments
\(1956 film\)"), [_Gone with the Wind_](/wiki/Gone_with_the_Wind_\(film\)
"Gone with the Wind \(film\)"), and _[Ben-Hur](/wiki/Ben-Hur_\(1959_film\)
"Ben-Hur \(1959 film\)")_ , were called "blockbusters" based purely on the
amount of money earned at the box office. Other terms for highly successful
films included: "spectacular" (_[The Wall Street
Journal](/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal "The Wall Street Journal")_)[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] and
"super-grosser" (_[New York Times](/wiki/New_York_Times "New York
Times")_).[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

In 1975 the usage of "blockbuster" for films coalesced around [Steven
Spielberg](/wiki/Steven_Spielberg "Steven Spielberg")'s
_[Jaws](/wiki/Jaws_\(film\) "Jaws \(film\)")_ , and became perceived as
something new: a cultural phenomenon, fast-paced exciting entertainment, which
became a common topic of conversation, inspiring repeated viewings.[3] The
film is regarded as the first film of the "blockbuster era", referring to this
as a film genre.[4] Although earlier films such as _Gone with the Wind_ (1939)
and [_The Sound of Music_](/wiki/The_Sound_of_Music_\(film\) "The Sound of
Music \(film\)") (1965) had made more in ticket sales (when adjusted for
inflation),[5] _Jaws_ ' domestic box office take in excess of $250 million[6]
was seen as a new standard for "blockbuster".[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] Two
years later, _[Star Wars](/wiki/Star_Wars_\(film\) "Star Wars \(film\)")_
expanded on the success of _Jaws_ , setting box office records and enjoying a
theatrical run that lasted more than a year.[7]

After the success of _Jaws_ and _Star Wars_ , many Hollywood producers
attempted to create similar "event" films with wide commercial appeal, and
film companies began [green-lighting](/wiki/Green-light "Green-light")
increasingly large-budget films, and relying extensively on massive
advertising blitzes leading up to their theatrical release. These two films
were the prototypes for the "summer blockbuster" trend,[8] in which [major
film studios](/wiki/Major_film_studio "Major film studio") and distributors
planned their annual marketing strategy around a big release by July 4,[9]
hoping to attract audiences over the summer, previously a moribund time for
ticket sales. Blockbusters in the following decade included _[Close Encounters
of the Third Kind](/wiki/Close_Encounters_of_the_Third_Kind "Close Encounters
of the Third Kind")_ (late 1977),[10] _[Superman](/wiki/Superman_\(1978_film\)
"Superman \(1978 film\)")_ (1978),[11] _[Alien](/wiki/Alien_\(film\) "Alien
\(film\)")_ (1979),[12] _[Raiders of the Lost
Ark](/wiki/Raiders_of_the_Lost_Ark "Raiders of the Lost Ark")_ (1981),[12]
[E.T.](/wiki/E.T._the_Extra-Terrestrial "E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial")
(1982),[12] [_Ghostbusters_](/wiki/Ghostbusters_\(franchise\) "Ghostbusters
\(franchise\)") (1984),[12] _[Beverly Hills Cop](/wiki/Beverly_Hills_Cop
"Beverly Hills Cop")_ (1984),[12] _[Back to the
Future](/wiki/Back_to_the_Future_\(franchise\) "Back to the Future
\(franchise\)")_ (1985).[12]

Eventually, the focus on creating blockbusters grew so intense that a backlash
occurred, with critics and some film-makers decrying the prevalence of a
"[blockbuster mentality](/wiki/Blockbuster_mentality "Blockbuster mentality")"
and lamenting the death of the author-driven, "more artistic" small-scale
films of the [New Hollywood](/wiki/New_Hollywood "New Hollywood") era. This
view is taken, for example, by film journalist [Peter
Biskind](/wiki/Peter_Biskind "Peter Biskind"), who wrote that all studios
wanted was another _Jaws_ , and as production costs rose, they were less
willing to take risks, and therefore based blockbusters on the "lowest common
denominators" of the mass market.[13] In his book _The Long Tail_ , [Chris
Anderson](/wiki/Chris_Anderson_\(writer\) "Chris Anderson \(writer\)") talks
about blockbuster films, stating that a society that is hit-driven, and makes
way and room for only those films that are expected to be a hit, is in fact a
limited society.[14]
